posts.name: Kerem Alper Batal
posts.cooked:
Hi Chief Delphi community,

We are working on our 2025 offseason robot using a swerve drive with YAGSL and are encountering a puzzling issue with a single module’s steering motor. Despite thorough documentation review and checking of usual suspects, we remain stuck and would appreciate any insights.

**Our Setup:**
- WPIlib: 2025
- Library: YAGSL (latest release version)
- Modules: SDS MK4i L2
- Steering Motors: NEO
- Drive Motors: NEO
- Absolute Encoders: CANcoder
- Gyro: PIGEON 2.0

**The Problem:**
The steering motor on our front-left module often fails to reach its commanded angle. Testing was conducted both on and off the ground, yet the issue persisted. Key symptoms include:
1. The CANcoder reads the module’s angle correctly, indicating the software knows it isn’t at the desired setpoint. However, the steering motor doesn’t apply sufficient power to correct its position when drive motors are active.
2. The issue is isolated to the front-left module, which works fine with the same PID settings.
3. Without the robot being enabled, manually rotating the wheel to the correct angle realigns the encoder and actual plots. Re-enabling the robot causes it to revert to the incorrect angle.

Interestingly, enabling `setModuleEncoderAutoSynchronize` solves the problem when the robot is stationary but reintroduces the issue upon starting drive commands.

**What We’ve Checked:**
- Configuration: YAGSL JSON files, CAN IDs, motor inversions, and CANcoder offsets were verified.
- Wiring: All CAN and power connections were inspected, showing no obvious issues.
- Mechanical: No signs of binding detected during manual rotation.
- Codebase: Using a fresh clone of the latest YAGSL example project.

Two videos demonstrate the issue: one shows the module failing to track while drive wheels spin, and another illustrates correct alignment when `setModuleEncoderAutoSynchronize` is enabled.

Has anyone encountered a similar issue where a single module’s steering fails to reach its commanded angle, even with no ground contact? Could this relate to a faulty motor/controller, an electrical noise issue on the CAN bus affecting only active drive motors, or something else overlooked?

Thank you for your assistance and insights.

posts.name: Austin Plummer
posts.cooked: Are you using press-fit pinions or keyed pinions on the steering motors?

The text is: EXTREMLY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH. The text is:

This is one of the best explanations and problem solving i have seen a team post!

So as you discovered (through excellent testing!) the issue is happening somewhere in between that motor and absolute encoder on ONE module. This means that if there is NOTHING DIFFERENT (except absolute encoder ID, offsets, motor ids) in that modules config its likely a hardware problem.

Worst case scenario you swap out that entire module. So i would HEAVILY scrutinize how that module was assembled, did you use the right pinion gear for the turning motor on that module? (Very common problem) Is the motor getting hot? Is there a loose screw in the bevel gear, etc.

Lastly i an sorry that this is happening but I sincerely applaud your problem solving skills that you have applied while trying to fix it!

After removing all HTML tags and adjusting for proper grammar and punctuation, the cleaned version is below. Changes include correcting "i" to "I", adding missing commas, and ensuring consistent capitalization. This is one of the best explanations and problem-solving techniques I’ve seen in a team post! So as you discovered (through excellent testing) the issue is occurring somewhere between the motor and absolute encoder on one module. This suggests that if nothing differs except the absolute encoder ID, offsets, or motor IDs in that module’s configuration, it’s likely a hardware problem. In the worst-case scenario, you might consider replacing the entire module. To thoroughly investigate, I recommend examining how the module was assembled. Did you use the correct pinion gear for the turning motor on that module? (A very common issue) Is the motor overheating? Are there loose screws in the bevel gear, for example? Lastly, I apologize for the situation but I truly commend your problem-solving skills demonstrated while attempting to resolve it.

posts.name: Kerem Alper Batal
posts.cooked: We are using press-fit with 8mm Push-On Retaining Rings. After reviewing the materials, we determined that our modules employ a distinct method. However, we wish to emphasize that all our modules utilize the same approach. Following further investigation, we plan to review the modules and provide updates to everyone involved.

posts.name: Kerem Alper Batal
posts.cooked:
Hi nstrike,

Thank you very much for the quick reply and the kind words! It truly motivates me to hear positive feedback about my work on YAGSL. This library has significantly improved my workflow, and I plan to continue using it for all my projects until I switch to CTRE products.

My objective was to clearly explain the problem in order to benefit everyone involved. I hope I won’t waste anyone’s time, especially yours, in providing assistance.

I am confident our configuration is accurate, so I fully agree with your suggestion. Upon receiving the new module, I will inspect its hardware closely. It was assembled by another team member, so there may be minor issues during assembly. I’ll provide an update once I’ve thoroughly inspected it.

The most puzzling issue remains unresolved: When disabling the robot and manually adjusting the wheel to the correct setting (verified via AdvantageScope), the motor snaps back to the incorrect angle as soon as it’s enabled again. Additionally, the `setModuleEncoderAutoSynchronize` function can temporarily fix this when the module is stationary.

This suggests a discrepancy between the motor’s integrated encoder and the CANcoder. To better understand this conflict, I have a clarifying question:

When a drive command is executed, does the system use the motor’s integrated encoder or the absolute CANcoder to determine the target position?

Insights into this could help identify the source of the inconsistency. Once again, thank you for your support and guidance!

posts.name: Kerem Alper Batal
posts.cooked: It is the last release of the YAGSL example code. We made changes to the configuration JSON files. The metadata was updated to version 2025.8.0. An issue related to fixed encoders on the Brushed SparkMax device was addressed. The full changelog spans from 2025.7.2 to 2025.8.0.

posts.name: Austin Plummer
posts.cooked:
When performing a press fit, especially with products like the steer motor, did you use a retaining compound such as 609 or 638 (Loctite)? We encountered a similar issue where the steer motor pinion slipped onto the motor shaft.  

Using Advantage Scope, comparing the steer motor position with the absolute encoder revealed discrepancies. This occurred because while the motor encoder reached its setpoint, the actual wheel position didn’t align due to the slipping pinion, resulting in mismatched wheel position readings.

I have noticed this issue occurring several times before. It typically stems from an incorrect pinion or gear on the swerve module's azimuth. This problem often arises because the motor's gear ratio doesn’t match the absolute encoder's ratio. It’s quite simple to identify and fix. By opening AdvantageScope and turning the module 360 degrees after synchronizing the encoders, you can resolve the issue effectively.

posts.name: Kerem Alper Batal
posts.cooked:
EXTREMELY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH. The text is:

Hi @nstrike and @Austin_Plummer,

Thank you both again for the excellent suggestions. I was finally able to get to our workshop today to do some detailed testing based on your advice.

To give the result upfront: the problem still exists, but your guidance helped me uncover and confirm a key symptom.

Here’s a summary of what I found:

1. Encoder Discrepancy Test (as suggested by nstrike): This was the most revealing test. After synchronizing the encoders, I manually rotated the problematic module a full 360 degrees while watching the data in AdvantageScope. I can confirm that the motor’s integrated encoder and the absolute CANcoder values are drifting apart.

  • After one full rotation, a discrepancy of about **5-15 degrees** appears between the two encoders.
  • This error is cumulative; the gap widens with each subsequent rotation.
  • This is also visually clear in the AdvantageScope swerve view: after a rotation, the blue (measured state) module no longer aligns with the red (desired state) module, even when the desired state is stationary.

2. Mechanical Inspection: Following the advice about a slipping pinion, I disassembled the module (while it was still on the chassis, I took apart the components except for the large bearing) and inspected the mechanics.

  • The steering motor pinion is the correct **14T** and felt very secure on the motor shaft.
  • The gear it meshes with is the correct **50T**.
  • The pulleys and belt also seemed to be in good condition with no visible issues. To be honest, my mechanical expertise is limited, but I could not see anything that looked obviously abnormal or loose. After I reassembled everything, the problem persisted.

3. Hardware Swaps: To further isolate the issue, I tried swapping components:

  • I replaced the **CANcoder** with a brand new one. The problem remained.
  • I swapped the **steering motor with the drive motor** on that same module. Since the SPARK MAX controllers are attached to the motors, this effectively swapped the controllers as well. The problem still remained with the steering function.

At this point, I’m running out of ideas. I am very confident it is not a software configuration issue, given the problem is isolated to this specific module and the configs are correct. It seems to be a very elusive hardware problem.

I also have a few specific questions:
  • CANcoder Magnet Mounting: When I replaced the CANcoder, I just press-fit the new magnet. Is there a best practice for this? Would you recommend using a retaining compound like Loctite, or is that not advised?
  • MK4 vs. MK4i Parts: We don’t have a spare MK4i module, but we do have older MK4 modules (both are L2 gear ratio). Are there any specific gears, bearings, or other mechanical parts that are compatible between the MK4 and MK4i that I could try swapping for testing?
  • Specific Part to Order: We likely can’t order a whole new module right now. Based on the encoder drift symptom, is there a specific component (e.g., a particular bearing that could be failing, the top bevel gear, etc.) you would suspect above others? If so, we could consider ordering just that specific part.
I am open to any other theories or suggestions you might have. Thank you again for your invaluable help in debugging this.

posts.name: Aidan
posts.cooked: kab: Would you recommend using a retaining compound like Loctite, or is that not advised? Absolutely! During one of our competitions with our mk4i modules, we faced issues with swerves. We discovered that the magnets lacked Loctite, causing them to slowly rotate and drift the CANcoder. Applying Loctite resolved the problem. I believe the assembly guide suggests using Loctite for magnets, though I'm uncertain. By the way, I really appreciate your detailed responses!
This could absolutely be the problem!

posts.name: Kerem Alper Batal
posts.cooked: Do you suggest any specific one for Loctite?

posts.name: Aidan
posts.cooked: The mk4i assembly guide suggests "609 Retaining Compound" for your project. Given your uncertainty about various Loctite types, this might just be the best option based on the recommendation.
